# Arpeggio: Dominant 7#5 in D (Shape: G)

An arpeggio is a broken chord where the notes of a chord are played in succession rather than simultaneously. The Dominant 7#5 arpeggio in the key of D consists of the notes D-F#-A#-C. In the G-shape position, this arpeggio is played on the guitar as follows:

- D (Fret 10 on low E string)
- A# (Fret 11 on A string)
- C (Fret 10 on D string)
- F# (Fret 11 on G string)

This arpeggio creates a unique and tense sound due to the augmented fifth (A#) and dominant seventh (C) intervals. It is often used to add dissonance and tension in jazz, fusion, and experimental music compositions.

## Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7#5 arpeggio in D played in the G-shape position provides a sharp and edgy flavor to compositions. The augmented fifth and dominant seventh intervals give it a dominant and unresolved sound, making it suitable for creating tension and adding color to musical pieces.
